revision.text:
{{for|the television series|1 Litre no Namida (TV series)}} {{Infobox book | name = 1 Litre no Namida | title_orig = 1リットルの涙 | translator = Ichi Rittoru no Namida | image = book of 1 Litre of Tears.jpg | caption = Original book of One Litre of Tears | author = [[Aya Kitō]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[Japan]] | language = [[Japanese language|Japanese]] | series = | subject = | genre = [[Non-fiction novel]] | publisher = [[Gentosha Inc.]] | release_date = Japan: February 25, 1986 | media_type = Print ([[Paperback]]) | pages = 270 pp | isbn = 978-4-344-40610-0 | isbn_note = (Japan)
{{ISBN|978-4-89684-495-5}} (USA) | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} {{Nihongo|'''''1 Litre no Namida'''''|1リットルの涙|Ichi Rittoru no Namida|lit. "1 Litre of Tears"; also called '''''A Diary with Tears''''' or '''''A Diary of Tears'''''}} is a dramatic [[tragedy]] diary written by {{nihongo|[[Aya Kitō]]|木藤亜也|Kitō Aya|July 19, 1962 - May 23, 1988}} published shortly before her death. The diary, a true story based on her own life, was originally written in first person. It is about a girl coping with her teenage life along with a degenerative disease. She keeps a diary of not only what she does but how she feels and the hardships she must endure. Initially, the diary's purpose was for Kitō to chronicle impressions she had about how the disease was affecting her daily life. As the disease progressed, however, the diary became Kitō's outlet for describing the intense personal struggles she underwent in coping, adapting, and ultimately trying to survive her disease. As she notes in one entry, "I write because writing is evidence that I am still alive." ==Plot summary== Aya Kitō was diagnosed with a disease called [[spinocerebellar degeneration]] when she was 15 years old. The disease causes the person to lose control over their body, but because the person can retain all mental ability the disease acts as a prison. So in the end she cannot eat, walk or talk. Through family, medical examinations and rehabilitations, and finally succumbing to the disease, Aya must cope with the disease and live on with life until her death at the age of 25. === Film === ''[[A Litre of Tears (film)|A Litre of Tears]]'' is the film version of the drama. === TV series === A Japanese TV drama, with the same title ''[[1 Litre no Namida (TV series)|1 Litre no Namida]]'', was aired by Fuji TV in 2005 based on the life of Aya. The main character Aya Ikeuchi, played by [[Erika Sawajiri]], depicts a girl with the same disease as Aya Kitō who goes through many of the same problems. A Indonesian TV drama, with the title [[Buku Harian Nayla]], was aired by [[RCTI]] in 2006 based on the life of Aya. The main character Nayla, played by [[Chelsea Olivia]], depicts a girl with the same disease as Aya Kitō who goes through many of the same problems. ==External links== *[http://diaryofaya-onelitreoftears.blogspot.com/ Diary Of Kaito Aya-chan] in English of 1 Litre of Tears *[http://diaryofaya.blogspot.com Diary of Aya] in English - translated from Chinese *[http://Aya-Kito-s-Diary.skyrock.com/ Aya-Kito-s-Diary's blog - Le Journal d'Aya Kito - Skyrock.com] Un litre de larmes, en français. *[http://unlitredelarmes.over-blog.fr Un litre de larmes, le journal d'Aya] traduction française du livre *[http://ildiariodiaya.blogspot.it il Diario di Aya] Traduzione italiana dall'inglese *[http://ikeuchi-aya.livejournal.com A Diary of Tears] in German - translated from English {{DEFAULTSORT:1 Litre No Namida}} [[Category:Japanese books]] [[Category:1986 books]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] [[Category:Diaries]]

{{other uses}} <!-- EDIT BELOW THIS LINE --> {{wiktionary|agon}}
'''Agon''' ([[Ancient Greek language|Classical Greek]] {{lang|grc|ἀγών}}) is an ancient Greek term for a struggle or contest. This could be a contest in athletics, in [[chariot#Greece|chariot]] or horse racing, or in music or literature at a public festival in ancient Greece. Agon is the word-forming element in 'agony', explaining the concept of agon(y) in [[tragedy]] by its fundamental characters, the [[protagonist]] and antagonist.
== Athletics ==
In one sense, agon meant a contest or a competition in athletics, for example, the [[Ancient Olympic games|Olympic Games]] (Ὀλυμπιακοὶ Ἀγῶνες). Agon was also a [[Greek mythology|mythological]] personification of the contests listed above.<ref name="DGRBM">{{Cite book| last = Schmitz | first = Leonhard | author-link = | contribution = Agon | editor-last = Smith | editor-first = William | title = [[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology]] | volume = 1 | page = 74 | publisher = [[Little, Brown and Company]] | place = Boston | year = 1867 | contribution-url = http://www.ancientlibrary.com/smith-bio/0083.html | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} }}</ref> This god was represented in a statue at [[Olympia, Greece|Olympia]] with ''[[halteres (ancient Greece)|halteres]]'' ([[dumbbells]]) ({{lang|grc|ἁλτῆρες}}) in his hands. This statue was a work of [[Dionysius (sculptor)|Dionysius]], and dedicated by Micythus of [[Rhegium]].<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], ''Description of Greece'', book V (Elis), v. 26. § 3</ref>
== Religion ==
Agon also referred to a challenge that was held in connection with [[religious festival]]s.<ref>Trapido (1949)</ref> With a further religious meaning as used in [[1 Timothy]] 6:12 in the [[New Testament]] and defined by [[Strong's Concordance]] as, agón: a gathering, contest, struggle; as an (athletic) contest; hence, a struggle (in the soul).<ref>[http://concordances.org/greek/73.htm Strong's Concordance]</ref>
== Theater ==
In [[Ancient Greek theatre|Ancient Greek drama]], particularly [[Old Comedy]] (fifth century B.C.),<ref>{{cite journal|last=Humphreys|first=Milton W.|title=The Agon of the Old Comedy|journal=The American Journal of Philology|date=1887|volume=8|issue=2| pages=179–206|doi=10.2307/287385|jstor=287385}}</ref> agon refers to a contest or debate between two characters - the prot''agonist'' and the ant''agonist'' - in the highly structured Classical [[tragedy|tragedies]] and [[drama]]s. The agon could also develop between an [[acting|actor]] and the [[choir]] or between two actors with half of the chorus supporting each. Through the argument of opposing principles, the agon in these performances resembled the dialectic dialogues of [[Plato]].<ref>["agon." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica Online Academic Edition. Encyclopædia Britannica Inc., 2014. Web. 17 Feb. 2014.]</ref> The meaning of the term has escaped the circumscriptions of its classical origins to signify, more generally, the conflict on which a literary work turns.
==Dance== In 1948, [[Lincoln Kirstein]] posed the idea of a ballet that would later become known as ''[[Agon (ballet)|Agon]]''. After ten years of work before ''Agon'''s premiere, it became the final ballet in a series of collaborations between choreographer [[George Balanchine]] and composer [[Igor Stravinsky]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Alm |first1=Irene |title=Stravinsky, Balanchine, and Agon: An Analysis Based on the Collaborative Process |journal=The Journal of Musicology |date=April 1989 |volume=7 |issue=2 |pages=254–269 |doi=10.2307/763771}}</ref> Balanchine referred to this ballet as "the most perfect work" to come out of the collaboration between Stravinsky and himself.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jordan |first1=Stephanie |title=Agon: A Musical/Choreographic Analysis |journal=Dance Research Journal |date=Autumn 1993 |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=1–12 |doi=10.2307/1478549}}</ref>
== Literature ==
[[Harold Bloom]] in ''The Western Canon'' uses the term ''agon'' to refer to the attempt by a writer to resolve an intellectual conflict between his ideas and the ideas of an influential predecessor in which "the larger swallows the smaller", such as in chapter 18, [[James Joyce|Joyce]]'s agon with [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]].
In "Man, Play, and Games" [[Roger Caillois]] uses the term Agon to define games of competitive nature.
== Sociopolitical theory == In sociopolitical theory, agon can refer to the idea that the clash of opposing forces necessarily results in growth and progress.<ref>Colaguori 2012</ref>
== Derivatives == Words derived from ''agon'' include [[wikt:agony|agony]], [[wikt:agonism|agonism]], [[wikt:antagonism|antagonism]], and [[wikt:protagonist|protagonist]].
==References== {{reflist}}
===Other sources=== * {{cite journal |last1=Trapido |first1=Joel |title=The Language of the Theatre: I. The Greeks and Romans |journal=Educational Theatre Journal |date=October 1949 |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=18–26 |doi=10.2307/3204106}} * {{cite thesis|first1=Dietrich|last1= Ramba |date=2014|title= Bestimmung der prägenden Wesenszüge im Sport der griechisch-römischen Antike|trans-title=Determination of the Poignant Characteristics of Sports in the Greco-Roman Antiquity|type=PhD| publisher=[[University of Göttingen]]|language=German|hdl=11858/00-1735-0000-0022-5EFD-8}} *{{cite book|author=Claudio Colaguori|title=Agon Culture: Competition, Conflict and the Problem of Domination|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3dS7XwAACAAJ|accessdate=7 May 2012|date=1 January 2012|publisher=de Sitter Publications|isbn=978-1-897160-63-3}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}}
[[Category:Ancient Greek theatre]] [[Category:Play (activity)]] [[Category:Personifications in Greek mythology]] [[Category:Greek gods]]

{{italic title}} [[File:Alciphron (1732) title page.jpg|thumb|''Alciphron'' title page (1732).]] '''''Alciphron''''', or '''''The Minute Philosopher''''' is an [[anticatholic]] philosophical [[dialogue]] by the 18th-century Irish philosopher [[George Berkeley]] wherein Berkeley combated the arguments of [[free-thinkers]] such as [[Bernard Mandeville|Mandeville]] and [[Anthony Ashley-Cooper, 3rd Earl of Shaftesbury|Shaftesbury]] against the [[Christianity|Christian]] [[religion]]. It was first published in 1732.
The dialogue is primarily between four characters, the free-thinkers Alciphron and Lysicles, Berkeley's spokesman Euphranor, and Crito, who serves as a spokesman for traditional Christianity. The mostly-silent narrator of the dialogue is given the name Dion.
The work contains two especially notable sections: * Dialogue IV, in which Berkeley presents a novel [[teleological argument]] for the existence of [[God]] based on Berkeley's theory of visual language, defended in the ''[[Essay Toward a New Theory of Vision]]'' (first published in 1709, and included with the first edition of ''Alciphron'').<ref>See David Kline, "Berkeley's Divine Language Argument" in Ernest Sosa, ed., ''Essays on the Philosophy of George Berkeley'' (Dordrecht: Reidel, 1987), repr. in David Berman, ed., ''Alciphron in Focus'' (London: Routledge, 1993).</ref> * Dialogue VII, in which Berkeley presents a novel theory of language which has been compared with the theory of language advocated by [[Ludwig Wittgenstein]] in his ''Philosophical Investigations''.<ref>Anthony Flew, "Was Berkeley a Precursor of Wittgenstein?" in W. B. Todd, ed. ''Hume and the Enlightenment: Essays Presented to Ernest Campbell Mossner'' (Edinburgh: The University Press, 1974), repr. in Berman, ed., ''Alciphron''.</ref> In a later work, ''[[The Theory of Vision Vindicated and Explained]]'' (first published in 1733), Berkeley adduced the work of [[Alberto Radicati]] as evidence that the views advocated by the character Lysicles were not overly exaggerated (para. 5).
== Notes == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://books.google.cz/books?id=SMiqYHR6xkMC&pg=PA11#v=onepage&q&f=false Literature Suppressed on Religious Grounds] from [[Google Books]] *[https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&id=pGQVAAAAYAAJ&dq=berkeley+alciphron&printsec=frontcover&source=web&ots=j-NiDQ6W7i&sig=mcePhbfbGe_8TrPwTQax6A0elH8&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result ''Alciphron, or the Minute Philosopher''] 1803 ed. from [[Google Books]] * [https://archive.org/details/worksofberkeley02berkuoft ''Alciphron, or The Minute Philosopher''] (''The Works of George Berkeley''. Ed. by [[Alexander Campbell Fraser]]. In 4 Volumes. Vol. 2. Oxford: [[Clarendon Press]], 1901) from [[Internet Archive]] *[http://www.earlymoderntexts.com Paraphrase of ''Alciphron'' at Early Modern Texts]
{{authoritycontrol}} [[Category:1732 books]] [[Category:Books by George Berkeley]] [[Category:Christian apologetic works]] [[Category:Philosophy of language literature]] [[Category:Dialogues]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | title = Bardia Mural | image_file = BardiaMural.jpg | caption = The mural in the 1950s | image_size = 400 | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[John Frederick Brill]] | catalogue = | year = {{start date|1942}} | type = [[Mural]] | material = | subject = | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = cm<!--don't leave blank—either don't include it, or include the default cm. --> | imperial_unit = in<!--don't leave blank—either don't include it, or include the default in. --> | condition = Damaged by graffiti, and a large crack in the wall | city = [[Bardia]], [[Libya]] | museum = | accession = | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = | url = <!--{{URL|example.com}} Only for official web pages--> }} The '''Bardia Mural''' was created in a building on a clifftop overlooking the bay in [[Bardia]], [[Libya]], during [[World War II]] by [[John Frederick Brill]] just prior to his death at the age of 22.<ref name="Commonwealth War Graves Commission"> {{cite web | last =Commonwealth War Graves Commission | url =http://www.cwgc.org/search/SearchResults.aspx?surname=Brill&initials=J+F&war=2&yearfrom=1942&yearto=1942&force=Army&nationality=&send.x=42&send.y=14 | title =Last Resting Place | accessdate =29 May 2006 }}</ref> It depicts a collage of images that range from the horrors of war shown by skulls to the memories of home, shown by wine, women and song.
The mural still exists and can still be visited. It has, however, been defaced and its state has declined with a large crack in the wall on which it was created. Much of the lower part of the mural is lost.
As of April 2009, renovation work had been started by Italian artists who have filled the cracks and replaced broken plaster. Parts of the mural have been cleaned removing graffiti and restoring some of the 'blackness' of the paint.<ref name="Donald Simmonds"> {{Cite web | last =Simmonds | first =Donald | url =http://www.don-simmonds.co.uk/restoration.htm | title =Restoration of Bardia Mural }}</ref> A photograph of John Brill painting his mother can be seen here.<ref name="Portrait"> {{cite web |last =Simmonds |first =Donald |url =http://www.don-simmonds.co.uk/index.htm |title =Bardiyah (Bardia) Mural by John Brill }}</ref>
== Mural description == [[File:Bardia07.JPG|thumb|The Bardia Mural building.]] As can be seen from the photograph taken in the sixties, while the mural was still largely intact, it originally depicted Brill's memories of home, as well as the horrors of war. From left to right images of a boxer overlay a newspaper, beneath which money and piles of skulls, are followed by grasping hands reaching up to repeated and overlaid images of apparently naked women, whose facial features change subtely. Above these women can be seen the artists signature reference to the [[Royal Army Service Corps|R.A.S.C.]] and the date of ''21 4 42'', with a further repetition of skulls above the signature. The image continues to unfold, on the other side of what appears to be a curtain separating the two sides of the mural, with pages of music, a grand piano and a table laid for a sumptious meal (many knives and forks), under which are fitted a number of books, which according to Lydia Pappas <ref name="Lydia Pappas"> {{cite web | last =Simmonds | first =Donald |author2=Lydia Pappas | url =http://www.don-simmonds.co.uk/latest.htm | title =Latest Updates | accessdate =28 May 2006 }}</ref> represent the works of [[Charles Dickens]] From left to right: ''[[A Tale of Two Cities]]''; ''[[Barnaby Rudge]]''; ''[[David Copperfield (novel)|David Copperfield]]''; ''[[The Old Curiosity Shop]]'' and ''The Pickwick Papers''. The image flows on to a conductor with more music, followed by a number of men's faces watching three ballet dancers, who are dancing on a floor of musical notes, the mural ends with the image of a face looking out of a window high up in a brick wall at the top right hand corner of the mural, which has variously been suggested to be the artist himself, or a relative back in "[[blighty]]" awaiting his return.
== History == [[Image:Alamein2.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Commonwealth War Cemetery, [[El Alamein]]. John's final resting place.]] According to his mother,<ref name="Letter from J Brill's Mother">{{cite web |last=Seccombe |first=John |url=http://bardiamural.pbwiki.com/%5BBardiaMural |title=Letter to John Seccombe from Brill's Mother |accessdate=30 May 2006}}</ref> Brill developed a passion for art at a young age. Having studied at the [[Royal Academy]], he then went on to pass the entrance exam to study a 3 year diploma course at the [[Royal College of Art]] when the war broke out. His mother wrote, "His creed was that in order to become a great artist, he must suffer. Consequently he joined the Infantry, believing that to be the roughest and hardest of the services."<ref name="Letter from J Brill's Mother" /> He fought in Europe and survived Dunkirk, after which his regiment was posted to the Middle East
John Frederick Brill was a Private in the 5th Battalion of the [[East Yorkshire Regiment]].<ref name="Commonwealth War Graves Commission"/> He signed the mural on 21 April 1942,<ref name="Signature">{{cite web |last=Simmonds |first=Donald |url=http://www.don-simmonds.co.uk/updates1.htm |title=Signature Close Up |accessdate=29 May 2006}}</ref> a matter of weeks before his death. He died on 1 July 1942, the first day of the [[First Battle of El Alamein]], aged 22.<ref name="Commonwealth War Graves Commission" /> He was buried at the El Alamein War Cemetery.<ref name="Commonwealth War Graves Commission" />
===Controversy=== Early versions of the history of the Bardia Mural involved controversy. While it is commonly accepted that the mural was painted with paint, some versions stated that the material used to create the murals was Boot Black.{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} There were also arguments over John's status when he painted the mural, indicating him as a [[prisoner of war]] or even under a [[death sentence]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} These three questions were referred to in a letter to the "Old Codgers" section of the ''[[Daily Mirror]]''.{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}}
Brill's mother Eliza later wrote a letter, to answer the controversies, on 31 January 1966, having been shown a copy of the article about the mural which she knew her son had painted before his death. In the letter she stated that he originally painted a mural on each of the "four walls of the lad's canteen, which represented 'A Soldier's leave in Cairo'. This - I understand, afforded them much interest & amusement".<ref name="Letter from J Brill's Mother" /> Following this the Officers asked Brill to create Murals in their Officer's Mess. According to John's mother the picture below represents one of these murals. The subjects being "The Pleasures of Avarice" and "The Pleasures of Art", and a third subject of "The Last Supper', "but this was never finished as his company was moved up the line." The Bardia Mural is likely to be one of these.<ref name="Letter from J Brill's Mother" /> She goes on in her letter to state "I am thankful to say, that he was not under sentence of death, neither was he ever a prisoner."<ref name="Letter from J Brill's Mother" /> She also states that the material used to create the various murals he painted during this period was paint, and not boot black; "paints were bought in Cairo, by the lads on leave and sent up by Convoy to Bardia. I understand that the costs were defrayed from the N.A.F.F.A. ''(sic)'' funds."<ref name="Letter from J Brill's Mother" /> It is likely that she meant to refer to [[NAAFI]] funds.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}}
== Images of the mural == [[Image:BardiaMural.jpg|thumb|left|550px|The Bardia Mural as it was seen in the 1950s somewhat cropped.]] {{clear}} Uncropped photographs<ref>[http://www.don-simmonds.co.uk 1960s Don-simmonds.co.uk]</ref> taken by Donald Simmonds that show signs of wear and tear even then.
More photographs<ref>[http://www.don-simmonds.co.uk/updates.htm Don-simmonds.co.uk]</ref> that show graffiti.
2009 photographs<ref>[http://www.don-simmonds.co.uk/restoration.htm Don-simmonds.co.uk]</ref> showing renovation in progress.
== References == <references/> * [http://www.don-simmonds.co.uk A constantly updated source (showing many enlargements) of material on the '''Bardia Mural''' accessed on 28 May 2006]
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060531052016/http://www.fpri.org/footnotes/103.200512.sanzare.libya.html FPRI.org], reference to the '''Bardia Mural''' by a U.S. visitor * [https://archive.is/20130210072207/http://www.yourmailinglistprovider.com/pubarchive_show_message_iframe.php?LibyaNews+1355 Yourmailinglistprovider.com], mention from another U.S. visitor * [http://www.don-simmonds.co.uk Don-simmonds.co.uk], latest updates including renovation * [https://maps.google.com/?ll=31.754299,25.093288&spn=0.067144,0.15398&t=h&om=1 link to Google Map]
{{coord|31.7543|25.0933|type:landmark_source:enwiki-googlemaplink|display=title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}}
[[Category:Murals|Bardia Mural]] [[Category:Arts in Libya]]

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=May 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Boogie Woogie | image = Boogie woogie ver2.jpg | border = yes | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = Duncan Ward | writer = Danny Moynihan | producer = Danny Moynihan
Kami Naghdi
[[Christopher Simon]]
Cat Villiers | starring = [[Gillian Anderson]]
[[Alan Cumming]]
[[Heather Graham (actress)|Heather Graham]]
[[Danny Huston]]
[[Christopher Lee]] | cinematography = [[John Mathieson (cinematographer)|John Mathieson]] | music = [[Janusz Podrazik]] | editing = Kant Pan | distributor = [[IFC Films]] (North America) | released = {{Film date|df=y|2009|6|26|[[Edinburgh International Film Festival|EIFF]]|2010|4|16|United Kingdom}} | country = United Kingdom | language = English | runtime = 94 minutes }} '''''Boogie Woogie''''' is a 2009 [[comedy film]] set in the [[art world]] of contemporary [[London]]. It is based on the book of the same name written by [[Danny Moynihan]], who adapted his own book on the New York art world of the 1990s and titled it based on ''[[Victory Boogie-Woogie]]'', a [[Piet Mondrian]] painting. The film was produced by [[Eric Eisner]] and [[Leonid Rozhetskin]], and directed by [[Duncan Ward]]. It stars [[Gillian Anderson]], [[Alan Cumming]], [[Stellan Skarsgaard]], [[Heather Graham (actress)|Heather Graham]], [[Danny Huston]], [[Amanda Seyfried]] and Sir [[Christopher Lee]]. It premiered on 26 June 2009 at the [[Edinburgh International Film Festival]].[http://www.edfilmfest.org.uk/whats-on/2009/boogie-woogie ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806025541/http://www.edfilmfest.org.uk/whats-on/2009/boogie-woogie |date=6 August 2009 }} == Plot == {{More plot|date=November 2015}} ''Boogie Woogie'' is a [[comedy of manners]], its cast of characters devouring each other in a small world awash with big money. Set against the backdrop of contemporary London and the international art scene, it casts an eye over the appetites and morality of some of its major players. Dealers, collectors, artists, and wannabes vie with each other in a world in which success and downfall rest on a thin edge. == Cast == * [[Gillian Anderson]] as Jean Maclestone * [[Alan Cumming]] as Dewey Dalamanatousis * [[Heather Graham]] as Beth Freemantle * [[Danny Huston]] as Art Spindle * [[Christopher Lee]] as Mr Alfred Rhinegold * [[Joanna Lumley]] as Mrs Alfreda Rhinegold * [[Charlotte Rampling]] as Emille * [[Amanda Seyfried]] as Paige Oppenheimer * [[Stellan Skarsgård]] as Bob Maclestone * [[Jaime Winstone]] as Elaine * [[Simon McBurney]] as Robert Freign * [[Meredith Ostrom]] as Joany * [[Gemma Atkinson]] as Charlotte Bailey * [[Jan Uddin]] as Art's Partner * [[Jack Huston]] as Jo Richards {{div col end}} ==Production== {{rquote|right|I hoped it would be a film from the start, and even wrote it in an [[Robert Altman|Altman-esque]] way, like ''[[Short Cuts]]'', but it took ten years.|Moynihan, on his novel and the film.}} Danny Moynihan's novel for ''Boogie Woogie'' was published in 2000, based on his [[hedonism|hedonistic]] New York years. [[Dennis Hopper]] originally held the [[option (filmmaking)|option]] to adapt the novel into a screenplay for a film to be set in New York City; later, Moynihan's friend, Duncan Ward, a documentary film-maker, became involved, with [[Rachel Weisz]] agreeing to play the "central, nubile gallerist" role eventually portrayed by Graham. After Weisz dropped out, producers switched the film's location to London for cost reasons; Moynihan "discovered then-unknown Amanda Seyfried living around the corner in [[Chelsea, London|Chelsea]]" and got her cast as an "art-world nymphet"; Charlotte Rampling, a family friend of Moynihan's, got a [[cameo appearance]]. [[Principal photography]] took place in London in December 2006.[http://www.stellanonline.com/boogie.html ''Boogie Woogie''], production notes from a fansite for Stellan Skarsgård ==Reception== Richard Clayton—in a ''[[The Sunday Times|Sunday Times]]'' article about the film that focuses on "who inspired its unsavoury characters"—called it "''[[The Devil Wears Prada (film)|The Devil Wears Prada]] and Hangs Out at Private Views'', but with a lot more sex and naughty bits." According to a [[National Public Radio]] review, "just about all the acting in this otherwise pedestrian satire is fabulous, and for want of other diversions you might amuse yourself itemizing all the squandered talent"; the film conflates "[[black comedy]] with cynicism" and "ends, dispiritingly, pretty much where it began."{{cite web| title= Boogie Woogie': Slick Moves Among The Art Mob| url= https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=126192774 | author= Ella Taylor| date= 22 April 2010 | publisher=[[National Public Radio]]| accessdate=2010-11-18 }} [[The Daily Beast]] called it a "dead-on satire of the contemporary art world that is loved by the very audience it savages."{{cite web| title= The Art World's Devil Wears Prada| date= 13 May 2010 |author= James Reginato | url= http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2010-05-13/the-art-worlds-devil-wears-prada/full/ | publisher= [[The Daily Beast]]| accessdate=2010-11-18}} [[Rex Reed]] called it a "tepid spoof that only occasionally evokes a reluctant smile" and said it "failed to capture the nuances or craft a more brutal, incisive exposé of the art milieu."{{cite web| title= ''Boogie Woogie'': You Call This Art?| date= 21 April 2010 |author= [[Rex Reed]] | url= http://www.observer.com/2010/culture/you-call-art | publisher= [[The New York Observer]]| accessdate=2010-11-18}} == References == {{reflist|refs= {{cite web| title= Boogie Woogie: sex, drugs and overpriced art| url= http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/film_reviews/article7091481.ece | date= 11 April 2010| publisher= [[The Sunday Times]]| accessdate =2010-11-17}} {{cite web | title= Interview: Danny Moynihan - The Boogie Woogie man| date= 12 April 2010| author= Nick Curtis | url= http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/movies/Interview-Danny-Moynihan--The.6217142.jp | accessdate=2010-11-18}} }} == External links == * {{IMDb title|1134664}} * {{amg title|492490}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boogie Woogie}} [[Category:2009 films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:2000s comedy films]] [[Category:British comedy films]] [[Category:Films set in London]] [[Category:Vertigo Films films]] [[Category:British LGBT-related films]] [[Category:Lesbian-related films]]

revision.text:
[[File:1104swabash.jpg|right|thumb|Center for Book and Paper Arts on Wabash]]
The '''Center for Book and Paper Arts''' is part of [[Columbia College Chicago]], located in [[Chicago, Illinois]]. The Center is the largest book-and-paper-arts teaching institution in the [[United States]], which is housed on the second floor of the historic [[Ludington Building]]. The Center teaches [[letterpress]], [[papermaking]], [[bookbinding]], [[artists' books|artists' book]] creation. The Center has a history of dedication to furthering knowledge and appreciation of [[book illustration|book arts]]".<ref>[http://www.colum.edu/book_and_paper/ "Columbia College Chicago Center for Book and Paper Arts Website"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090512143659/http://www.colum.edu/Book_and_Paper/ |date=2009-05-12 }}, Retrieved 19 Nov 2009.</ref> In addition to teaching classes for interested individuals from the community, the Center is part of the [[Interdisciplinary arts]] Department at [[Columbia College Chicago]], whose programs include an MFA in Interdisciplinary Book and Paper Arts.<ref>Julia Steinberger, [https://web.archive.org/web/20030614050757/http://centerstagechicago.com/art/galleries/center-for-book-arts.html "Columbia College Chicago Center for Book and Paper Arts"], www.centerstagechicago.com. Retrieved 3 May 2009.</ref>
The [[Interdisciplinary arts]] Department full-time faculty who teach at the Center for Book and Paper Arts primarily include: Director and Associate Professor [https://web.archive.org/web/20100123002829/http://www.melissapotter.com/ Melissa Potter] and lecturer [[Miriam Schaer]].
The Center for Book and Paper Arts also has a large {{convert|4000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} gallery space whose exhibition history includes work by [[Enrique Chagoya]], [[Bruno Richard]], a 2008 exhibition of the iconic manuscript scroll of ''[[On the Road]]'' by [[Jack Kerouac]], and a 2009 exhibition featuring Buddhist Printing techniques from the [[Derge Parkhang]].<ref>[http://www.colum.edu/book_and_paper/CBPA_Exhibitions/index.php "Center for Book and Paper Arts, Exhibitions"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091112225534/http://www.colum.edu/book_and_paper/CBPA_Exhibitions/index.php |date=November 12, 2009 }} Retrieved August 19, 2009.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} *[http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/reviews/velez/center-for-book-arts-4-5-11.asp/ Bookworms in Nerd Heaven]
==External links== *[http://www.colum.edu/academics/book-and-paper/ Center for Book and Paper Arts Website] *[http://www.colum.edu/interarts/ Interdisciplinary Arts Department Website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090816111805/http://jab.lib.uchicago.edu/ Journal of Artists Books Website, published at the Center for Book and Paper Arts]
[[Category:Columbia College Chicago]] [[Category:Book arts]] [[Category:Art galleries in Chicago]]

{{Infobox Theatre |name = Chisenhale Dance Space |image = External_view_of_Chisenhale_Dance_Space,_London,_June_2015.jpg |caption = Chisenhale Dance Space |address = 64 – 84 Chisenhale Road, London, E3 5QZ |city = [[London]] |country = |designation = |coordinates = {{coord|51.5330|-0.0396|type:landmark|display=inline}} |architect = |owner = |capacity = |type = |opened = 1984 |yearsactive = |rebuilt = |closed = |othernames = |production = |currentuse = |website = [http://www.chisenhaledancespace.co.uk/ http://www.chisenhaledancespace.co.uk] }}
'''Chisenhale Dance Space''' is a British, member-led charitable organisation<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithoutPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=288149&SubsidiaryNumber=0 |title=288149 – Chisenhale Dance Space Limited |website=Charity Commission|accessdate=8 May 2015}}</ref> based in east [[London]]. It provides rehearsal and performance space for independent dancers.
It was founded in the early 1980s by members of the [[X6 Dance Collective]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://suite.io/amy-watson-2/5kmc2mw |title=X6 Collective and the History of British Contemporary Dance |first=Amy |last=Watson |website=Suite|accessdate=8 May 2015}}</ref> who were originally housed in [[Butler's Wharf]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://exeuntmagazine.com/features/body-politics/ |title=Body Politics |first=Hamish |last=MacPherson |website=Exeunt Magazine |date=27 September 2013 |accessdate=8 May 2015}}</ref> It officially opened as a public performance space in December 1984.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Jordan|first1=Stephanie|title=Striding Out|date=1992|publisher=Dance Books Ltd.|location=London|isbn=1 85273 032 3|pages=85–86}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Mackrell|first1=Judith|title=Out of Line: The Story of British New Dance|date=1992|publisher=Dance Books Ltd.|location=London|isbn=1 85273 038 2|pages=46–49}}</ref>
The organisation is based on the top floor of a former veneer factory near [[Victoria Park, London|Victoria Park]] in the [[London Borough of Tower Hamlets]]. The space comprises offices, dance studios and a 75-seater theatre and performance space<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/resources/theatres/show/3633-chisenhale-dance-space |title=Chisenhale Dance Space |website=Theatres Trust|accessdate=8 May 2015}}</ref> which is available for professional and community use. [[Chisenhale Gallery]] and Chisenhale Art Place are situated in the same former factory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chisenhale.co.uk/|title=Chisenhale Art Place}}</ref>
The Chisenhale Dance Space focus is artist development, experimentation, research, and the creation of new dance and movement works.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2011/jan/30/underground-arts-dance-counterculture |title=Spirit of the underground: dance |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |first=John |last=O'Mahony |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=8 May 2015}}</ref> Their projects consist of artist development programmes and community outreach, such as Inspiring Young Londoners Through Dance, which was part of the Transformers scheme to celebrate the [[2012 Summer Olympics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transformers-1.org.uk/funded-projects/round-1-awards/chisenhale-dance-space |title=Chisenhale Dance Space |website=Transformers Grants Programme |accessdate=8 May 2015}}</ref>
The theatre space is used for dance festivals, live performances and dance-related film screenings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/dance/home-made-festival |title=Home Made Festival |website=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]] |accessdate=8 May 2015}}</ref> The space’s 30th anniversary film programme included a screening of ''[[Hail the New Puritan]]'' – a fictionalised documentary starring [[Michael Clark (dancer)|Michael Clark]] and directed by [[Charles Atlas (Media Dance)|Charles Atlas]] – which was filmed in Chisenhale Dance Space.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://londondance.com/articles/news/chisenhale-dance-space-celebrates-the-big-30/ |title=Chisenhale Dance Space celebrates The Big 30 |first=Carmel |last=Smith |date=10 September 2013 |website=London Dance|accessdate=8 May 2015}}</ref>
Chisenhale Dance Space is part of the Tower Hamlets Dance Partnership. The other members are East London Dance,<ref>{{cite web|title=East London Dance|url=http://www.eastlondondance.org/|website=East London Dance|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref> Green Candle Dance Company,<ref>{{cite web|title=Green Candle Dance Company|url=http://www.greencandledance.com/participation/young/|website=Green Candle Dance Company|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref> [[Trinity Laban Conservatoire of Music and Dance]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Trinity Laban|url=http://www.trinitylaban.ac.uk/|website=Trinity Laban|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref> and [[Central Foundation Girls' School]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Central Foundation Girls' School|url=http://www.central.towerhamlets.sch.uk/|website=Central Foundation Girls' School|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=THAMES|url=http://webfronter.com/towerhamlets/thames/menu/mnu1.shtml#m-liid_360955|website=THAMES|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.chisenhaledancespace.co.uk// Chisenhale Dance Space's official website]
[[Category:Contemporary dance in London]] [[Category:Charities based in London]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1984]] [[Category:Dance venues in England]] [[Category:1984 establishments in England]]

A '''combination company''' was a theatrical [[touring company]] which performed only one [[Play (theatre)|play]]. Unlike [[repertory]] companies, which performed multiple plays in rotation, combination companies used more elaborate and specialized scenery in their productions. Repertory theatre had been popular in the United States through the 19th century, and it is not clear how the combination system originated. Combination companies contributed to the early success of [[Broadway theatre]], as most combination companies began their tours in [[New York City]]. Combination companies were fueled by stars. The Star agenda or star system that had been set in place in mid 19th century America helped greatly in the development of the combination company. The idea of celebrity was at full force and people would flock to theater houses to see their favorite stars perform. Stars made famous in New York would travel to stock theaters and perform limited engagements there. “The engagements of the first important stars… were rare and special events”(Poggi 4). Audiences would come in from all over to sold out performances at playhouses and see their favorite stars. The Stock companies would cancel their normal repertory programs for a few nights to allow for the show of the star. The star would be supported by the local company of actors in the play, which proved to be very frustrating to them (Poggi 5). After the star left, the company returned to its repertory schedule as per usual. Yet annoyed by the lack of talent from regional companies, the stars began to search for companies to tour with them. They began to tour with two or three actors, and then eventually whole companies would tour with them and they would perform a repertory of plays (Wilmeth 200-201). This switch to companies that support the stars for the whole tour was one more step in the transition from stock companies to combination companies.
== Repertory vs. combination == Repertory companies, both those in residence and those on tour, featured several actors who rehearsed multiple plays which were performed in rotation, adding and removing shows from their repertoire over time. Repertory theaters, also known as ''stock theaters'', generally employed generic [[theatrical properties]] for use in each of their productions. This system was popular throughout the [[United States]] in the 19th century (Somerset-Ward).
Because combination companies only performed a single play, they were not restricted by the need to use generic properties. Combination companies took advantage of this fact by specializing each asset of the company—actors, rehearsals, [[Theatrical scenery|scenery]], properties, costumes and personnel—to tailor to the needs of the one play being performed (Londré). In particular, this enabled combination companies to use more elaborate scenery than their repertory counterparts (Somerset-Ward).
== Origin == It is not entirely clear how the combination system originated. American actress [[Laura Keene]] toured with a combination company as early as 1862. American actor [[Joseph Jefferson]] claimed that both he and [[Charles Wyndham (actor)|Charles Wyndham]] independently established the combination system in 1868 with their productions of ''[[Rip van Winkle]]'' and ''[[The Lancers]]'', respectively. The advent of the [[First Transcontinental Railroad]] may have contributed to the success of touring companies (Londré).
Many early touring companies found success by exclusively performing renditions of the immensely popular [[Uncle Tom's Cabin]], an anti-[[slavery]] novel published in 1852 by [[Harriet Beecher Stowe]]. In 1927, 75 years after Uncle Tom's Cabin had been published, these renditions, known as [[Tom Shows]] (Londré), were still being performed exclusively by twelve combination companies worldwide (Somerset-Ward).
Most of the combination companies in the United States rehearsed and began their tours in [[New York City]], which contributed to the early success of what would eventually be known as [[Broadway theatre]]. The combination company system was so successful throughout the United States that [[Dion Boucicault]], an Irish actor and playwright, brought it to England for the first tour of his play ''[[The Colleen Bawn]]'' in the 1860s (Somerset-Ward).
== Circuits and the syndicate == Another way the combination business was run was through circuits. Local managers struggled with finding a continuous flow of touring companies, because it required them to take multiple trips to New York to make deals with producers. “Booking a successful season of touring productions was a complex gamble for the theatre manager,” so the solution was to create a travel circuit. (Toten Beard 35). A travel circuit is when a group of the theaters all in the same state or neighboring states would band together under one theater manager who would then go to New York to make deals with the Broadway Producers (Toten Beard 25). This idea was much more beneficial for the producer because it provided multiple stops of a tour all guaranteed under one business deal and made tour planning much simpler. It was helpful to the local theater managers because it provided a steady stream of business to help keep their theater afloat and also helped them to get the most popular and raved about shows to travel through their city (Poggi10). This soon grew into managers from theaters in a large city taking advantage of the smaller theaters by buying them out or making them pay interest to the larger theater (Poggi 10). M.B. Leavitt was the manager of a popular theater in San Francisco and is given the credit of developing “loosely organized circuits” into centralized booking agencies, which controlled the theatre in large segments of the country (Poggi 11). He did this by adding small theaters from Omaha to San Francisco to the circuit and having them pay him to provide for the traveling expenses of the company. This brought attention to the company because they would be guaranteed sold out one-night stands in smaller towns and a sold out long run in San Francisco (Poggi 10-11). This became the foundation of what became a Syndicate. Through the centralization of booking, booking agents became extremely important in negotiations between local managers and circuit representatives. These booking agencies grew in power by monopolizing all the theaters in a certain region of America, claiming “that it was more efficient for a theater or a circuit to do all its booking through one agency” (Poggi 11). In 1896 the ultimate monopoly of the theater booking industry of traveling companies was created. It was called the [[Theatrical Syndicate]] and was formed by six booking agents who pooled together thirty-three of the top theaters from major cities around the country, which were then called Syndicate houses (Poggi 11). If a producer played in one Syndicate house on his tour then every city he performed in, if there was a syndicate house there, he would have to perform at that house and no other theater (Poggi 12). The Syndicate was the foremost business power in Theater during the late 1800s and early 1900s and was very similar to the other “giant ‘trusts’ of its day”(Poggi 13). It had no competition so it was able to choose its prices and fees that it took from the producers, managers and circuits under their control and demanded percentages of the profits of the shows. It was the height of the centralization of the theater business (Poggi 13-14). The Theatrical Syndicate allowed for the business of touring shows and combination companies to be managed in one centralized place, New York City. The Syndicate began to lose power with what is called the death of the road and the rise of motion pictures.
== The death of the road == The death of the road started happening after 1915 due to sinking profits, increased travel expenses and lower quality touring productions (Toten Beard 37). Theater began to be based in New York with no intentions of touring, because the Syndicate monopoly had been corrupted and was producing low art productions (Toten Beard 37). New York became the producing center and the most important city for producing theater. The long runs were reestablished and producers now began looking for the next best play that could last multiple performances. Also the rise of motion pictures drew audiences away from touring shows, because they offered the same stars and entertainment but at a cheaper price and more diverse productions. Slowly but surely playhouses converted back to regional theaters and combination companies became non-existent.
== Sources == *{{cite book | title = The history of North American Theater | author = Londré, Felicia Hardison and Daniel J. Watermeier | publisher = Continuum Intl Pub Group | location = New York | pages = 184–185 | isbn = 978-0-8264-1079-5}} *Poggi, Jack. Theater in America; the Impact of Economic Forces, 1870-1967. Ithaca, NY: Cornell UP, 1968 *{{cite book | title = An American Theatre: The Story of the Westport Country Playhouse | author = Somerset-Ward, Richard | publisher = Yale University Press | location = New Haven | year = 2005 | isbn = 0-300-10648-3 | pages = 13–14}} *"Stock Company | Theatre." Encyclopædia Britannica Online. Encyclopædia Britannica, n.d. Web. 25 Feb. 2015 *Toten Beard, DeAnna. Sheldon Cheney’s Theatre Arts Magazine: Promoting a Modern American Theatre, 1916-1921. Lanham, Maryland: Scarecrow Press, 2010 *Wilmeth, Don B., and C. W. E. Bigsby. "A Changing Theatre: New York and Beyond." The Cambridge History of American Theatre. Vol. 2. Cambridge: Cambridge UP, 1999
{{DEFAULTSORT:Combination Company}} [[Category:Theatre]] [[Category:19th-century theatre]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me | image = Elaine Stritch Shoot Me.jpg | border = yes | alt = | caption = | director = Chiemi Karasawa | producer = Chiemi Karasawa
Elizabeth Hemmerdinger | starring = [[Elaine Stritch]] | music = [[Kris Bowers|Kristopher Bowers]] | cinematography = Shane Sigler
Joshua Z. Weinstein
Rod Lamborn | editing = Kjerstin Rossi
Pax Wassermann | studio = | distributor = [[IFC Films|Sundance Selects]] | released = {{Film date|2013|04|19|Tribeca Film Festival|2014|2|20|United States}} | runtime = 81 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $288,896{{cite web|title=''Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me''|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=elainestritch.htm|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=15 April 2014|quote=Domestic Total as of Apr. 13, 2014}} }} '''''Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me''''' is a 2013 documentary film directed by Chiemi Karasawa about the life and career of [[Elaine Stritch]].{{cite news|last=Holden|first=Stephen|title=Recalling Velvet, Pretzels and Beer, She’s Still Here|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/21/movies/elaine-stritch-shoot-me-goes-backstage-with-a-legend.html|accessdate=22 February 2014|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=20 February 2014}} [[Alec Baldwin]] and [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] producer Cheryl Wiesenfeld served as executive producers on the film. It opened in theaters on 21 February 2014, shortly before Stritch's death in July 2014.{{cite news|last=Weber|first=Bruce|title=Elaine Stritch, Broadway’s Enduring Dame, Dies at 89|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/18/theater/elaine-stritch-tart-tongued-broadway-actress-and-singer-is-dead-at-89.html?_r=1|accessdate=16 September 2014|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=18 July 2014}} Karasawa and crew began following Stritch in 2011, she was 86 at the time.{{cite news|work=Rolling Stone|title=Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/elaine-stritch-shoot-me-20140221|date=February 21, 2014}} ==Subjects== In addition to [[Elaine Stritch|Stritch]], several of her close friends and collaborators were featured in the film: *[[Alec Baldwin]] *Rob Bowman *[[Tina Fey]] *[[James Gandolfini]] *[[Paul Iacono]] *[[Cherry Jones]] *Julie Keyes *[[Nathan Lane]] *[[Tracy Morgan]] *[[Harold Prince]] *[[John Turturro]] *[[George C. Wolfe]] The film was also dedicated to the memory of [[James Gandolfini|Gandolfini]], who died before it was released.{{cite news|work=[[News24]]|title=James Gandolfini died of cardiac arrest|agency=Associated Press|url=http://www.channel24.co.za/TV/News/James-Gandolfini-died-of-cardiac-arrest-20130620|date=June 20, 2013}} ==Release== The film had limited release in US theaters on 21 February 2014. It has been released to [[video on demand]]{{cite news|last=Hetrick |first=Adam |title="Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me" Documentary Now Available On Demand |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/188895-Elaine-Stritch-Shoot-Me-Documentary-Now-Available-On-Demand |accessdate=15 April 2014 |newspaper=Playbill.com |date=17 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140318104910/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/188895-Elaine-Stritch-Shoot-Me-Documentary-Now-Available-On-Demand |archivedate=18 March 2014 |df= }} and was later available on [[Netflix]]. {{cite news|last=Bernstein|first=Paula|title=8 New Documentaries Streaming on Netflix Now: 'Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me,' 'Gideon's Army' and More|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/8-new-documentaries-streaming-on-netflix-now-elaine-stritch-shoot-me-gideons-army-and-more-20140725|accessdate=16 September 2014|newspaper=Indiewire|date=25 July 2014}} ==Reception== ''Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me'' holds a 98% rating at Rotten Tomatoes from 53 reviews. The critical consensus reads: "Brutally honest and utterly compelling, ''Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me'' offers a riveting, vanity-free portrait of its legendary subject while offering a few essential truths about the [[human condition]]."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/elaine_stritch_shoot_me_2013/|title=Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=14 April 2014}} Jake Coyle of [[The Associated Press]] called it "an irresistibly entertaining documentary that captures Stritch during what she unsentimentally calls 'almost post-time.' After seven decades performing in [[New York City|New York]] — on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], in countless [[cabaret]] nights at the [[Cafe Carlyle]] — Stritch's enormous energy has been knocked by the increasing years, [[diabetes]], and surgeries on her hip and eyes. But ''Shoot Me'', made over the last few years, is a document not of Stritch's dwindling, but of her feisty persistence."{{cite news|last=Coyle|first=Jake|title=Movie review: 'Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me'|url=http://www.masslive.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2014/03/movie_review_elaine_stritch_sh.html|accessdate=15 April 2014|newspaper=''[[Associated Press]]''|date=26 March 2014}} == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == *{{official website|http://www.elainestritchshootme.com}} *{{IMDb title|2405792}} *{{rotten tomatoes|id=elaine_stritch_shoot_me_2013|title=Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me}} * {{allrovi movie|579045}} * {{YouTube|zQysjiUA68U|''Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me'' trailer}} [[Category:2013 films]] [[Category:2010s documentary films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Documentary films about actors]] [[Category:Documentary films about singers]] [[Category:Films shot in New York City]] [[Category:Documentary films about women]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=August 2011}} [[File:Arch of Traianus, Ancona - Tasso in Prison; - the Bridge of Sighs.jpg|thumb|upright=1.7|''[[Torquato Tasso#La Gerusalemme Liberata|Jerusalem Delivered]], an Heroic Poem'', translated from the Italian of [[Torquato Tasso]], by John Hoole. London 1797; with fore-edge painting: ''[[Arch of Trajan (Ancona)|Trajan's Arch]]'', ([[Ancona]]), ''Tasso in Prison'', and the ''[[Bridge of Sighs]]'']] A '''fore-edge painting''' is a scene [[Painting|painted]] on the edges of the pages of a [[book]]. There are two basic forms, including paintings on edges that have been fanned and edges that are closed; thus with the first instance a book edge must be fanned to see the painting and in the second the painting is on the closed edge itself and thus should not be fanned. A fanned painting is one that is not visible when the book is closed.
In order to view the painting, the [[Bookbinding#Terms and techniques|leaves]] of the book must be fanned, exposing the edges of the pages and thereby the painting. Another basic difference is that a painting on the closed edge is painted directly on the surface of the book edge (the fore-edge being the opposite of the spine side). For the fanned painting the watercolor is applied to the top or bottom margin (recto or verso) of the page/leaf and not to the actual "fore"-edge itself.
==Variations== A '''single fore-edge painting''' includes a painting on only one side of the book page edges. Generally, [[Gilding|gilt]] or [[Paper marbling|marbling]] is applied by the [[Bookbinding|bookbinder]] after the painting has dried, so as to make the painting completely invisible when the book is closed.
A '''double fore-edge painting''' has paintings on both sides of the page margin so that one painting is visible when the leaves are fanned one way, and the other is visible when the leaves are fanned the other way.
A '''triple fore-edge painting''' has, in addition to paintings on the edges, a third painting applied directly to the edges (in lieu of gilt or marbling). Edge paintings that are continuous scenes wrapped around more than one edge are called '''panoramic fore-edge painting'''. These are sometimes called a 'triple edge painting'.<ref name=Bromer>{{cite web|last=Bromer|first=Anne C.|title=Fore Edge Painting - An Introduction|url=http://foreedge.bpl.org/node/923|work=On the Edge: The Hidden Art of Fore-Edge Book Painting|publisher=Boston Public Library|accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref><ref name=Frost>{{cite web|last=Frost|first=Martin|title=What Is A Fore-Edge Painting?|url=http://foreedge.bpl.org/node/2|work=On the Edge: The Hidden Art of Fore-Edge Book Painting|publisher=Boston Public Library|accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref>
A '''split''' '''double painting''' has two different illustrations, one on either side of the center of the book. When the book is laid open in the center, one illustration is seen on the edges of the first half of the book, and another illustration is on the edge of the second half of the book.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/lovely-hidden-paintings-adorned-the-edges-of-historic-books|title=Lovely Hidden Paintings Adorned the Edges of Historic Books|date=2016-09-29|work=Atlas Obscura|access-date=2017-10-19|language=en}}</ref>
There are even examples of rare variations that require the pages of the book to be pinched or tented in a certain way to see the image.<ref name=":0" />
==History== The earliest fore-edge paintings date possibly as far back as the 10th century; these earliest paintings were symbolic designs. Early [[England|English]] fore-edge paintings, believed to date to the 14th century, presented [[Heraldry|heraldic]] designs in gold and other colors. The first known example of a ''disappearing'' fore-edge painting (where the painting is not visible when the book is closed) dates from 1649. The earliest signed and dated fore-edge painting dates to 1653: a family coat of arms painted on a 1651 [[Bible]].
There is an interesting legend of how hidden fore-edge painting on books supposedly first began: Charles II of England had a lady friend, a duchess, who often borrowed his books, sometimes forgetting to return them. As the story goes, the king commissioned the court painter, Sir [[Peter Lely]], and the court bookbinder, [[Samuel Mearne]], to devise a secret method in which his books could be identified. Between the two they worked out a unique plan. Some weeks later, when the king was visiting the duchess he spotted a familiar looking book on a shelf. Taking it down he said, “I’ll just take my book along with me.” “But sire,” the lady protested, “that book is mine.” “Oh?" The king raised his brows. Then, with a sly smile, he fanned out the book and revealed what had been painted on the inner edges--the royal coat of arms. The gilding on the outer edges had completely hidden the identification. Acknowledging that Charles had outwitted her, the duchess sank in a deep curtsy before her king.<ref>Dutter, Vera, E. [http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/51833306/ancient-art-fore-edge-painting "The Ancient Art of Fore-Edge Painting"], ''[[American Artist]]'', January 1969. Retrieved on 3 March 2018</ref>{{better source needed|date=May 2018}}
Around 1750, the subject matter of fore-edge paintings changed from simply decorative or heraldic designs to [[Landscape art|landscapes]], [[portraits]] and religious scenes, usually painted in full color. Modern fore-edge painted scenes have a lot more variation as they can depict numerous subjects not found on earlier specimens. These include scenes that are erotic, or they might involve scenes from novels (like Jules Verne, Sherlock Holmes or Dickens, etc.). In many cases, the chosen scene will depict a subject related to the book, but in other cases it did not. In one instance, the same [[New Brunswick]] landscape was applied to both a Bible and to a collection of poetry and plays. The choice of scenes is made by either the artist, bookseller or owner, thus the variety is wide.
The technique was popularized in the 18th century by John Brindley (1732 - 1756),<ref>{{Cite book | title = ABC For Book Collectors | last = Carter | first = John | last2 = Barker | first2 = Nicolas | publisher = Oak Knoll Books | year = 2010 | isbn = 9781584561125 | location = New Castle, DE | pages = 108 }}</ref> publisher and bookbinder to the prince of Wales.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/search_the_collection_database/term_details.aspx?bioId=14739 | title = John Brindley | last = | first = | date = | website = The British Museum | publisher = | access-date = February 29, 2016 }}</ref> and Edwards of Halifax, a distinguished family of bookbinders and booksellers.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://cool.conservation-us.org/don/dt/dt1157.html | title = Etherington & Roberts. Dictionary--Edwards of Halifax | website = cool.conservation-us.org | access-date = 2016-02-29 }}</ref>
The majority of extant examples of fore-edge painting date to the late 19th and early 20th centuries on reproductions of books originally published in the early 19th century.
Artists currently expert in the fore-edge artform include UK-based artists, Martin Frost and Clare Brooksbank. The reference book of L. Jeff Weber lists many artists' and binders' names associated with this art form, including those working presently (until 2010).
==Collections== No comprehensive census of fore-edge paintings in the United States has yet been completed.
*[[College of William and Mary]]'s [[Earl Gregg Swem Library]] holds a collection of 709 fore-edge paintings in the Ralph H. Wark Collection, the largest collection of fore-edge painted books in America.<ref name="Ralph H. Wark Collection">{{cite web|title=Ralph H. Wark Collection|url=https://swem.wm.edu/research/special-collections/books-periodicals/ralph-h-wark-collection|publisher=Earl Gregg Swem Library, College of William and Mary| website= WM.edu|accessdate=10 September 2013}}</ref>
*[[Boston Public Library]] has a collection of 258 fore-edge paintings, one of the larger collections in the United States, and many examples are displayed online.<ref name=Figenbaum>{{cite web|last=Figenbaum|first=Muriel C.|title=The Albert H. Wiggin Collection|url=http://foreedge.bpl.org/node/704|work=On the Edge: The Hidden Art of Fore-Edge Book Painting |publisher= Boston Public Library|accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref>
*Estelle Doheny Collection housed in the Edward Laurence Doheny Memorial Library at St. John’s Seminary, Camarillo, California, is described as "roughly twice as large" as the collection at the Boston Public Library.<ref name="Figenbaum"/>
*[[University of New Mexico]]'s Center for Southwest Research & Special Collections holds 102 fore-edge paintings from the collection of Lucia von Borosini Batten of Albuquerque. Many were formerly owned by Estelle Doheny, who married her husband, oil baron [[Edward L. Doheny]], in New Mexico Territory in 1900. Three paintings by Miss C. B. Currie are available.{{cn|date=August 2017}}
*[[Syracuse University]]'s Special Collections Research Center has the Poushter Collection, with more than 90 volumes.<ref name= weber>{{cite web|last=Weber|first=Jeff|title=Fore-edge Paintings at Syracuse University |date= Fall 1992| url= http://surface.syr.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1282&context=libassoc|work=The Courier |publisher= Syracuse University| accessdate= 6 May 2016}}</ref>
*[[Louisiana State University]] Library holds at least 37 fore-edge paintings in its Rare Book Collection. Several are probably by the artist identified by Jeff Weber as the "American City View Painter".{{cn|date=August 2017}}
*[[Clark University]] holds the [[Robert H. Goddard Library]]'s Rare Book Collection, which includes 17 books with fore-edge paintings.<ref>{{cite web| url= https://www2.clarku.edu/research/archives/rarebooks/foreedge.cfm| title= Archives and Special Collections: Fore-edge Paintings| website= clarku.edu| publisher= Clark University| date= | access-date= August 29, 2017}}</ref>
*Mudd Library at [[Lawrence University]] has a varied collection of books with fore-edge art that were donated by two alumnae, Dorothy Ross Pain Lawrence class of 1918, and Bernice Davis Fligman Milwaukee-Downer class of 1922.<ref>{{cite web| url= https://blogs.lawrence.edu/library-special-collections/category/fore-edge-paintings | title= Fore-edge Paintings| website= lawrence.edu| publisher= Lawrence University| date= December 16, 2013| access-date= August 29, 2017}}</ref>
*[[Hofstra University]] has in their collection a few fore-edge books, some of which are ''Les Psaumes de David'' and ''Outlines from the Figures and Compositions upon the Greek, Roman and Etruscan Vases of the Late Sir William Hamilton''.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.hofstra.edu/pdf/library/lib_sc_fore_edged_srp.pdf | website= Hofstra.edu| title= Fore-Edge Paintings| first= Jennie| last= Stramiello |publisher= Hofstra University | date= | access-date= August 29, 2017}}</ref>
[[File:Tower of London surrounded by houses and an meadow with walking people - Fore-edge painting, KW1740F2.jpg|thumb|Fore-edge painting of the [[Tower of London]], 1820-1840]] *[[George Peabody Library]] in Baltimore, Maryland also contains a collection of books with fore-edge paintings within its Dorothy McIlvain Scott Collection.{{cn|date=August 2017}}
* The [[National Library of the Netherlands]] has a few fore-edge books, e.g. [http://opc4.kb.nl/DB=1/PPN?PPN=401682137 KW 1740 F 1] (a pendrawing and [[Watercolor painting|aquarelle]] in shades of blue, green, yellow and red,depicting a lake surrounded by mountains and on the righthand side a castle with docking place and boats) and [http://opc4.kb.nl/DB=1/PPN?PPN=401682153 KW 1740 F 2] (a pendrawing and aquarelle in shades of blue, green and red, depicting the [[Tower of London]] surrounded by houses and an meadow with walking people), [http://opc4.kb.nl/DB=1/PPN?PPN=401720233 1786 B 24] or [http://opc4.kb.nl/DB=1/PPN?PPN=401709906 1773 D 25].
==Gallery== <gallery mode="packed" caption="Images from the Dorothy McIlvain Scott Collection at George Peabody Library"> File:Childe Harold's Pilreimage Fore-Edge Painting.jpg|''[[Childe Harold's Pilgrimage]]'' (Lord Byron, 1812-1818) File:The New Casket Fore-Edge Painting.jpg|''The New Casket'' (1850) by [[Joseph Martin Kronheim]] File:Sacred Poetry Fore-Edge Painting.jpg|''Sacred Poetry'' ([[Jeremy Belknap]], 1744) File:Rogers' Poems Fore-Edge Painting.jpg|''Rogers' Poems'' ([[Samuel Rogers]], 1834) File:The Sports and Pastimes of the People of England.jpg|''Sports and Pastimes of the People of England'' ([[Joseph Strutt (engraver and antiquary)|Joseph Strutt]], 1801) </gallery>

{{Book structure}}
[[Category:Painting techniques]] [[Category:Book design]] [[Category:Book arts]] [[Category:Bookbinding]] [[Category:Illuminated manuscripts]]

The '''Guild of Women-Binders''' was an organization founded to promote and distribute the work of women [[Bookbinding|bookbinders]] at the turn of the 20th century. It was founded by Frank (Francis) Karslake in 1898, and disbanded in 1904. It helped sell bindings produced by women binders already practicing, and instituted training programs to teach other women. [[File:-Single works. Pilgrim's Progress, Pt. 1, 2. English - The Pilgrim's Progress ... With original notes by the Rev. Thomas Scott ... The thirteenth edition, including the poetry hitherto omitt - Upper cover and spine (C108b17).jpg|thumb|An edition of ''[[The Pilgrim's Progress]]'' produced by the Guild of Women Binders, held at the [[British Library]]. Likely bound by Gwladys Edwards.]]
Frank Karslake was a [[London]] [[Bookselling|bookseller]], and a founder and financial backer of the Hampstead Bindery.<ref name="ABM blog">{{cite web|title=The Bindings Of To-Morrow|url=http://bookbindersmuseum.org/the-bindings-of-to-morrow/|website=American Bookbinders' Museum Blog|publisher=American Bookbinders' Museum|accessdate=8 March 2017}}</ref> At the 1897 Victorian Era Exhibition at [[Earls Court Exhibition Centre|Earl's Court]], he encountered several bindings by women, including [[Annie S. Macdonald]], on display, and his interest was piqued. Soon after, he invited several women binders to exhibit their work in his London shop; this "Exhibition of Artistic Bookbinding by Women," which ran from November 1897 to February 1898, garnered a substantial amount of interest from the public, and convinced him that promoting women's bookbindings could be a profitable venture, if perhaps partially for the novelty.<ref name="fincham">{{cite journal|last1=Fincham|first1=Ernest C.|title=Women as bookbinders|journal=Hearth and Home (reprinted)|date=1901|url=https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951t000266796|accessdate=11 March 2017}}</ref> Whatever his motivations, Karslake soon began acting as an agent to women binders already practicing, such as Annie MacDonald and Edith and Florence de Rheims.<ref name="ABM blog" />
By May 1898, the Guild of Women Binders was open as a business venture, headquartered at Karslake's bookstore at 61 [[Charing Cross Road]]. Karslake "saw that more money could be made by teaching to bind than by only binding and selling books.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tidcombe|first1=Marianne|title=Women bookbinders 1880-1920|date=1996|publisher=Oak Knoll Press|location=New Castle, DE|isbn=9781884718236|page=28}}</ref> He maintained that women were well-suited to be bookbinders, due to their "inborn reverence for the beautiful" and their deftness of hand.<ref name="express">{{cite journal|title=Bookbinding as a profession for women|journal=Daily Express|date=1901|url=https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951t000266796|accessdate=11 March 2017}}</ref> He focused on both promoting the work of women already engaged in bookbinding, and training additional women to create bindings. Every member of the Guild received training in hand-bookbinding, and were offered employment after they completed this training.<ref name="ABM blog" /> [[File:Poems Descriptive of Rural Life and Scenery - Upper cover (c108bbb8).jpg|thumb|An edition of "Poems descriptive of rural life and scenery" by [[John Clare]], produced by the Guild of Women Binders, held at the [[British Library]].]]
Members and associates of the Guild of Women Binders carved out a niche for themselves at the end of the 19th century by producing fine, artistic bindings by hand in an era when bookbinding was becoming increasingly mechanized. As part of its training efforts, the Guild set up a workshop, headed by Karslake's daughter Constance, near the Hampstead Bindery in 1899.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tidcombe|first1=Marianne|title=Women bookbinders 1880-1920|date=1996|publisher=Oak Knoll Press|location=New Castle, DE|isbn=9781884718236|pages=115, 120}}</ref> The Guild accepted for training only women with an art school background, likely limiting them to a small pool of middle-class women; by 1903, they had an estimated 25-30 students.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tidcombe|first1=Marianne|title=Women bookbinders 1880-1920|date=1996|publisher=Oak Knoll Press|location=New Castle, DE|isbn=9781884718236|page=122}}</ref> In keeping with the artistic styles of the time, many of the bindings featured [[Art Nouveau]] patterns, with sweeping lines and elegantly curved shapes. Karslake's advertising claimed that each binding was decorated with a unique pattern, though several patterns seem to have been variations of others.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tidcombe|first1=Marianne|title=Women bookbinders 1880-1920|date=1996|publisher=Oak Knoll Press|location=New Castle, DE|isbn=9781884718236|page=126}}</ref>
The Guild promoted and sold not only its own bindings, but also those of other groups such as the Chiswick Art Guild.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tidcombe|first1=Marianne|title=Women bookbinders 1880-1920|date=1996|publisher=Oak Knoll Press|location=New Castle, DE|isbn=9781884718236|page=96}}</ref> Consequently, the presence of a stamp of the Guild of Women Binders on a book may not necessarily mean that it was created by the Guild unless the individual binder can be identified, and may mean "little more than a bookseller's stamp."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tidcombe|first1=Marianne|title=Women bookbinders 1880-1920|date=1996|publisher=Oak Knoll Press|location=New Castle, DE|isbn=9781884718236|page=115}}</ref>
Ultimately, the Guild was not a successful business venture, possibly due to Karslake's inexperience in the professional bookbinding world (despite his associations with several binding operations, he had never worked as a binder himself). Karslake had tried to grow the Guild too far and too fast, taking on more students than teachers, and expecting too much out of his teaching staff.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tidcombe|first1=Marianne|title=Women bookbinders 1880-1920|date=1996|publisher=Oak Knoll Press|location=New Castle, DE|isbn=9781884718236|page=28}}</ref> Some professional bookbinders suspected that the bindings were too sophisticated to have been produced by women, especially recently trained ones; a few even accused Karslake of passing off the work of the Hampstead Bindery as Guild work. Potential buyers began to mistrust Karslake and the guild's products (with some justification, as Karslake and his workshops had little knowledge of sound bookbinding techniques such as those practiced by other [[Arts and Crafts movement|Arts and Crafts]] binders of the time), and many bindings went unsold.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tidcombe|first1=Marianne|title=Women bookbinders 1880-1920|date=1996|publisher=Oak Knoll Press|location=New Castle, DE|isbn=9781884718236|page=129}}</ref> The Guild was shuttered in 1904, leaving Karslake bankrupt and many of the women who had worked with him tainted by the controversy (though some did go on to continue independent careers as bookbinders).<ref name="ABM blog" />
==Incomplete list of women binders associated with the Guild== * [[Annie S. Macdonald]] * Ella Bailey * Constance Karslake * Olive Karslake * Edith de Rheims * Florence de Rheims * Helen Schofield * Mrs. Frances Knight * Lilian Overton * Hélène Cox * Mary Downing * Muriel Driffield * Gertrude Giles * Dorothy Holmes * Ethel Slater * H. W. Sym * Gertrude Stiles * Gwladys Edwards
